First things first, because this was extensively discussed in the forums: the controls in Space Marine 2 definitely need some getting used to. They‚Äôre a bit overloaded with ranged combat, melee combat and various parry and dodge mechanics. This requires a bit of experimenting until you find a control scheme that suits you. I ended up binding melee to the F key with parry on mouse 4 and aiming on the right mouse button. With this, the controls felt okay for the most part. Still, I feel this game might play better with a controller. On Jumppack: I liked those controls better in the first game.

This is not a game in which you do everything and kill everything by yourself. The tyranid enemies are so plentiful that you can‚Äôt get them all. So in single player, a good number of them will be handled by the AI companions. In co-op mode, your teammates will also take care of a good chunk of them, of course. Battles can get pretty chaotic at times and maintaining oversight of what happens gets challenging sometimes, which I think is intentionally and somewhat true to the source material.

Gameplay wise, the closest comparison is obviously Space Marine 1, but the game reminded me a bit of Red Faction Armageddon at first. Later, I got a bit nostalgic of Dark Souls, since you‚Äôll come across a lot of churches in which you can dodge-roll through the church pews - just like in FromSofts game.

I‚Äôm not sure if I like the mechanic of the co-op missions being so much intertwined with the campaign. I always tried to select the next mission I would play based on what would make the most sense to me story-wise. That meant frequently switching game modes from campaign to co-op and vice versa. This is not a seamless process at all though, since it requires some loading screens and character setup, the latter not really being there in the campaign. Also, the co-op missions are a bit immersion breaking in terms of storytelling, since the gameplay dynamic is of course a bit different there, especially If you play the campaign in single player. Co-op can also be played privately with bots, but that makes them much harder and is besides their intention - they‚Äôre meant to be played with three human players. The campaign itself is great and I very much enjoyed playing through it.

That co-op mode, called ‚ÄòOperations‚Äô, has character customization and a perk leveling system. This means that most sessions play out with people rushing through the levels while trying to get as many kills as possible and going through the mission as fast as possible, because kills and completing missions both give you XP. So naturally, most players want to go through fast for quicker leveling up. I‚Äôm not a fan of that I must say, because as I was trying to enjoy the levels and their surroundings, taking my time and finding all the dataslates, this rushing of the other people really sometimes destroyed said enjoyment to some degree. The experience depends on how you and your teammates play, so your mileage may vary.

There‚Äôs also another co-op mode called ‚ÄòSiege‚Äô, which is a horde mode that throws endless waves of enemies at you. Not really what I‚Äôm interested in. Besides that, they also included a multiplayer PvP mode, but I‚Äôm not into competitive multiplayer at all, so I can‚Äôt comment on and won‚Äôt judge that mode.

Graphics are great, the game looks stunningly beautiful and very detailed. Likewise, the sound is superb for the most part. I have absolutely no complaints about the game‚Äôs tech. It‚Äôs very polished and it runs very well, between 90 and 110 fps for me, playing on a 5 year old 3060 Ti with pretty high settings and DLSS set to Quality. This was kind of surprising for me, since I thought that I would struggle to maintain 60 fps. But that was no issue at all. Granted, I only played it in 1080p.

All in all, I did not enjoy this game as much as I did Space Marine 1, which I really liked a whole lot. Other than the graphics, I‚Äôm struggling to find any real improvements compared to its predecessor, which came out 13 years before this one. Operations mode is basically Vermintide light, the horde mode lacks long-term motivation for me. Objectively speaking though, I realize that this is a very good game. It‚Äôs well made, runs great and offers variety with its set of different game modes, some of them complementing each other. So I recommend this game to you if you‚Äôre looking for a third-person shooter with a heavy emphasis on melee combat and if you like the first Space Marine game. It just didn‚Äôt fully click with me.

Similar games that I can also recommend: Space Marine 1 (obviously), Red Faction Armageddon, Vermintide 2, Lost Planet 3

The amount of love, care, and attention to detail that was put in this game is staggering. The devs really have brought the world of 40k to life beautifully in this game. The environments, the set pieces, the epic battles raging on everywhere, not to mention the characters, are just so overwhelmingly well done that it's difficult not to just stare at everything. 

The campaign is a spectacularly executed epic which on its own is well-worth your time. After that, there are (currently 10) single missions called Operations which are full-fledged 30-45 minute experiences each, rich in detail and flavour, that add a lot of extra content and variety. Plus a wave-based endless mode, daily/weekly challenge operations, and PVP. So quite a lot overall. 

Outside of the campaign, you can play multiple different classes, unlock cosmetics, build your own custom armour from a variety of chapters, earn perks, masteries, skins, etc. etc. Great fun in co-op!

The only downside is the difficulty, which is in my opinion not suitable for casual gamers that just want to experience the world. Even the lowest difficulty is quite hard when you're starting out, and above that it quickly escalates. The worst offender is a new PvE Chaos enemy called the spawn which simply tanks all your hits, rushes in, and then takes off all your health faster than you can blink. It's extremely hard to learn to parry their entire moveset, and while a single one is usually manageable, they always come in pretty big groups that are nigh-impossible to deal with.

Also, the bots are almost totally useless, as they deal decreased damage, enemies kinda ignore them, and bots don't complete mission objectives or try to prevent enemy reinforcement waves from being called in. Playing with bots on the first difficulty level is harder than playing with other people on the third one. So playing with others is almost mandatory.

I enjoy Space Marine 2 overall and plan to continue putting time into its multiplayer. However, I want to highlight the issues that may be major detractors for others, especially anyone on the fence.

[h2]Combat & Difficulty[/h2]
Enemy damage in this game is extremely bursty. It‚Äôs very easy to get killed quickly, which makes the overall experience feel punishing‚Äîsometimes more than it should. You do have defensive tools like dodge and parry, and a successful parry lets you perform a gun strike. The issue is that gun strikes offer no invincibility, so you can get interrupted or simply overwhelmed before the move can help you. When encounters get chaotic (which they often do), this can create a lot of frustration. Higher difficulties also add more elite enemies, which only amplifies these problems.

[h2]Cutscenes & Pacing[/h2]
The game opens with an unskippable cutscene‚Äîworth noting for players on a refund timer or for anyone who dislikes story segments. Everything afterward can be skipped, but the opener might annoy people who just want to get into gameplay.

Pacing is another issue. The game has a lot of stop-and-go moments: move forward, fight enemies, walk to the next objective, wait for a story segment to finish, and repeat. For a game clearly designed with replayability in mind‚Äîespecially with its co-op Operations mode‚Äîit‚Äôs odd that the campaign has so many forced pauses baked in.

[h2]The Rat Mission[/h2]
There is one mission in the campaign involving a massive swarm of rats, and it‚Äôs genuinely awful. The rats can instantly kill you, and these deaths feel abrupt, unfair, and frustrating. It‚Äôs a low point in the design, and it stands out sharply from the otherwise more conventional mission structure.

[h2]What the Game Does Well[/h2]
Despite those issues, I do find the core gameplay fun. Mowing down hordes as a Space Marine feels great, and the weapon feedback is excellent. The game also includes multiple classes in its multiplayer Operations mode, and each one has different builds that offer meaningful character expression and variety in how you tear through Chaos or Xenos forces. This part of the game is engaging and keeps me coming back.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Space Marine 2 has clear strengths‚Äîsatisfying combat, strong class variety, and fun co-op‚Äîbut also notable flaws in pacing, encounter design, and difficulty tuning. If you're willing to push through some frustrating moments, there‚Äôs a solid action game underneath, but its rough edges may be deal-breakers for some players.

The long awaited sequel to the hidden gem that was the first Space Marine game, comes larger swarms of enemies, size, details and scale of the world faithful to the Warhammer 40k universe, memorable characters and scenes to view. The gameplay is smooth, having elements of both third person shooters without a cover system, and a fleshed out hack and slash gameplay against enemies in melee combat.

The campaign story takes place in the Indomitus crusade era of Warhammer 40k which happens after 8th edition so every space marine in this game is a primaris space marine despite firstborns still existing in lore. Titus returns from the first game along with some new faces of both Gadriel and Chairon fighting against Tyranids [spoiler] and Thousand Sons traitor warband [/spoiler]. 

I personally do not want to nitpick Space Marine 2 because the devs at Sabre Interactive put a lot of genuine care to their game and respected their audience in terms of free gameplay updates, and less anti-consumer practices of other game studios, but compared to the 1st space marine game there are a few pet peeves of mine. The weapons feel and sound like oversized assault rifles rather than the heavy hitting bolter rounds described in lore, the marines don't feel as heavy as in the first game, and combat is more akin to a souls-lite than feeling like an unstoppable juggernaut, but that is just my opinion.

Despite the mind-blowing campaign and replayable operations mode, the PvP mode is not as good because the teams do not get mixed after finishing a match which leads to one team winning over and over again until people inevitable leave, chaos customizations is limited compared to their loyalist counterparts since the game focuses on loyalist space marines.

Overall, a fun game to play especially with friends considering the 3 player campaign, operations, and horde mode are all PvE, experience to gain to unlock weapon upgrades, class perks and character customization. The game is periodically updated to always add something refreshing to play and work for, a breath of fresh air in the modern gaming world when players are losing faith with most AAA game studios.

The game gets the overall atmosphere and visual style right. The maps and set pieces are actually pretty neat and detailed, and the backdrops, particularly the live battlefields (where you will see hundreds, if not housands, or combatants that you can ACTUALLY SHOOT) are extremely immersive. Also the whole mechanic of Tyranid swarms trying to charge you atop of a wall, with you mowing down dozens of them in salvos, is done well.

Buuuuuut that's kinda all the good points already mentions. The game's performance isn't great, which is the reason I refunded it *twice* on my two previous rigs, the one not being able to boot the game at all, the other stuttering to much in the early levels for me to keep it. After getting a new PC (and, to clarify, this one's hardware is absolutely overproportionate and hasn't run any recent title at less than maximum FPS) I decided to give it a 3rd try, and it does run stable now. If only barely.

Story-wise, the 8h campaign is rather simplistic with only minor twists that you would have to be daft not to see coming. The soundscape is likewise bland, and the game utterly fails to make any of the weapons feel actually good to use. At one point I heard a faint buzzing noise from around a corner, rounded it, and came to face an NPC tank mowing down a tyrannid swarm with a heavy bolter. I was legitimately dumbfounded at how absolutely undertuned the weapons sound effects were.

Now, this could maybe all be overlooked if at least the gameplay was exciting. But it was likewise forgettable. There are some interesting points, particularly early in the campaign, but once you get past the tyranid bit, the gameplay legitimately takes a turn for the worse because at least the tyranids felt interesting to fight due to their slightly less orthodox tactics.
Guns, as mentioned, don't feel to great, and the bigger enemies are both bullet spongy, and incentivize you to deal with them in melee, thus emphasizing that kind of close range combat. Yet the melee combat system barely deserves to be called that, and is essentially a single-button system that has very, VERY little variety or thought beyond 'slap the enemy until he winds up a parryable attack with a big glowing indictator, slap him another time for good measure, than leisurely press the second-long parry'. 

Now, after the campaign, the game technically has a number of Coop PvE missions and a PvP mode, with some light class customization and stuff... but I'll be honest, the gunplay was so damn dull, I'm not exactly motivated to even try that out, and will instead just go back to Darktide (which, by the by, gets the sound design of the weapons done so much better it's amazing how they didn't just copy that).
